extractions.description: The paper presents a method to ensure the energy sufficiency of a robot during long-term missions in unknown and unstructured environments using Control Barrier Functions (CBFs). This framework provides energy sufficiency guarantees by overlaying an energy-aware layer on top of any path planner. The method was validated both in simulations and with physical robots equipped with full localization and mapping stacks.

title.value: Energy Sufficiency in Unknown Environments via Control Barrier Functions
title.justification: The title is directly extracted from the paper and succinctly encapsulates the main theme of the research, which is to ensure energy sufficiency in unknown environments using Control Barrier Functions.
title.quote: Energy Sufficiency in Unknown Environments via Control Barrier Functions

type.justification: The paper involves simulation experiments and real-world tests on robots to validate the proposed energy sufficiency framework, which aligns with the characteristics of empirical research.
type.quote: The framework is validated through physics-based simulation and on a physical AgileX Scout Mini rover.

research_field.justification: The paper centers around using advanced control functions that could integrate with learning algorithms for efficient path planning and energy management, which fall under the broad scope of Deep Learning applications in robotics.
research_field.quote: In this work, we present a modular and mission-agnostic framework that uses a Control Barrier Function (CBF) to guarantee energy sufficiency when applied alongside an arbitrary exploration planner.

sub_research_field.justification: The specific focus of the paper is on robotic path planning and control to optimize energy usage, which situates it within the subfield of Robotic Planning and Control.
sub_research_field.quote: The approach builds upon our previous work, which provides energy-sufficiency guarantees for robots in obstacle-free environments.

name.justification: The GBPlanner model is used in the study as an exploration planner to generate paths for robots.
name.quote: Several well-designed exploration planners exist in literature, many of which developed within the scope of the DARPA SubTerranian Challenge (DARPA 2018): the Graph-Based exploration planner (GBPlanner).

type.justification: GBPlanner is utilized for generating exploration and homing paths for the robot, which is pivotal for the study's experiments.
type.quote: In this work, we use the GBPlanner to generate both exploration and homing paths.
